div1.p: Andrus is Dead; “Guinea Pig” for Yellow Fever

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, New York Herald Tribune, May 3, 1942
div1.p:
One of 16 Army Volunteers
Who Let Doctors Inject
Germs in Search for Cure

PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--John
Andrus, an enlisted man in the
United States Army during the
Spanish-American War who sub-
mitted to an injection of yellow fever
germs when doctors sought the source
of the disease, died Friday at Phila-
delphia Naval Hospital. He was
sixty-two years old and lived at Cam-
den, N. J., where he was advertising
manager of the R. M. Hollingshead
Company.

One of sixteen volunteers to be
subjected to the germs on Jan. 28,
1901, Mr. Andrus was critically ill
for several months while Dr. Walter
Reed and others traced the course
of the illness. On his recovery he
received a bonus of $200 from the
Army. He was honorably discharged
on April 24, 1902.

On his return to Camden Mr.
Andrus formed an advertising com-
pany. Later a movement was begun
to give Mr. Andrus formal recogni-
tion, a medal and a pension of
$1,250 a year. Action to gain the
recognition and pension for Mr.
Andrus was unsuccessful for some
time, but Mr. Andrus received the
pension and the Congressional Medal
of Honor after President Herbert
Hoover signed a special bill provid-
ing for it for him and other volun-
teers.

Mr. Andrus enlisted in the Army
in 1899 and was transferred to the
hospital corps the next year. It was
from this corps that Dr. Reed called
for volunteers, with the warning
that the experiment in all likelihood
would end in death for those willing
to undergo it. During the World
War Mr. Andrus organized the New
Jersey State Militia Reserves, com-
manding the group with the rank of
major.

Surviving are his wife, Mrs. Anna
Andrus, a son, Dr. David L. Andrus,
with whom he lived; two brothers,
Vernon B. Andrus and Chester J.
Andrus, and a sister, Mrs. Mary
Goodwin.
